data.author: InvestPest
data.content: I keep reviewing the recent losses and then revisiting the September 11th announcement regarding NIU. It stated that "NIU Invest (NIU) contributed both MTV and Tataki Mine to GCR Group, which is headquartered in the United States." I also noted that NIU Invest intends to become an integrated mining operator with assets in North America, Latin America, Africa, and Europe, so doesn't appear to be going anywhere just building up. Its increased stake in CRTM appears to align with this wider expansion strategy. For that reason, I believe the recent share price uplift is more closely linked to NIU/GCR’s broader growth story rather than being solely tied to Molulu as such less likely susceptible to a share dump. GCR’s advisory board includes a former U.S. Army Brigadier General, which had me wondering about the Trump interest in growing the sector and seem to hvae the ability to buy some of the larger projects and meet senior politicians (“joining President Duma Boko (Botswana), who will officiate the opening of the mine, hosted by American firm GCR Group”). Developments like these are clearly influencing sentiment and, in turn, the share price. I can’t find any share listing for GCR’s Chilean or Botswana assets, but the trajectory indicates a much larger play than Molulu on its own. While pledges don’t always translate to execution, in this case capital has already been deployed with $200 million reportedly invested to revive and upgrade operations in Botswana, expected to generate more than 400 direct jobs and 3,000 indirect ones. Current job boards show over 40 vacancies posted, which reflects progress, though not yet the full scale announced. Even if Fryer decides to exit his position, it may not derail the bigger picture. At present, the momentum driving CRTM seems tied to its association with GCR/NIU’s moves rather than isolated project developments.  The big difference is Molulu isn't mining or holding reserves or Fryer could have pulled the wool over investor eyes again. Hopefully post rain season theres reporting of actually mining.

data.author: InvestPest
data.content: Did anyone see PXC crash yesterday after CRTM former non exec director Marcus Edwards-Jones and CFO Richard Wilkins suspended with immediate effect from their roles at Phoenix Copper Limited (PXC) Conduct Allegations: Recent professional conduct of both executives. Historical Payments: Specific "historic payments" made to Lloyd Edwards-Jones S.A.S., which is a firm co-founded by Marcus Edwards-Jones and formerly served as the company's corporate finance adviser. Clearly insider dealing and self enrichment going on. On the other forum: Payment to Riverfort deemed as a ‘preference’. There has to be a question from Indigo Capital, and on the same basis, NIU, regarding the context and timing of the raising of the funds by PXC from Indigo, and the repayment/prepayment of Riverfort with those funds raised from Indigo. At the time of the payment to Riverfort, was PXC knowingly trading in cash flow insolvency? If Indigo and/or NIU can argue that PXC was technically insolvent at the time that it repaid Riverfort, either or both of them would have good grounds to argue that PXC has given preference to Riverfort in its payment to it as a creditor. These factors are material issues to PXC as BOD’s, and to any potential future funder/investors at this time. Of course Indigo and NIU are going to be asking these questions of PXC at this time, looking for ways to secure their positions as best they can. It would be naive of anyone investing in PXC not to consider this is the situation. The ramifications are that it: (a) slows any new funding down essentially to a halt, unless or until questions including misreps and preference questions have been satisfactorily answered to the positive; and (b) open the question that if Indigo were misrepresented by PXC, will Indigo rescind the current financing; and (c) opens the question that if Indigo and/or NIU can argue that PXC was technically insolvent at the time that it repaid/prepaid Riverfort whether that payment be recalled to PXC, as it was deemed to be paid in preference over other creditors?

data.author: InvestPest
data.content: CRTM website: Danilo Lange "He has held senior management roles at Serviceplan Group and Redbull". Reading into them it turns out an 'Anna Lange' took on a new position of Chief Executive Officer at Serviceplan Group Rus, starting from February 2021 (pre-war) after Danilo Lange (previously headed the group in Russia) moved to become a board member. Anna Lange working career begun at Red Bull communications coincidentally, so perhaps a future CRTM board member in the making. Other similar agency networks after the invasion with major European presences, such as Serviceplan and Media.Monks remained. CRTM website also omits Langes Auriant Mining AB connection replacing with only 'CEO of a gold producer'. Auriant Mining, through its subsidiary LLC Tardan Gold (named after the Tardan deposit), is involved in geological exploration and gold mining in Russia. So at least the company complies with local Russian mining regulations, but its paying substantial taxes to the Russian government, which indirectly supports the Russian economy, including its military expenditure. Ignoring all that at least hes a history in mining!!!

I noted the GCR news as the reference was critical metals plc ( https://dnanews.com.pk/ktrade-hosts-global-mining-investor-delegation-in-pakistan/) and then started looking at who GCR are and the connection to NIU. Looks like a lot of activity and CRTM names just being thrown in as a connected mine within a group as opposed stand alone. Problem is the other assets arent share listed but appear much larger in scale. Sadly missed the rise.

data.author: natemc

data.author: InvestPest
data.content: I keep reviewing the recent losses and then revisiting the September 11th announcement regarding NIU. It stated that "NIU Invest (NIU) contributed both MTV and Tataki Mine to GCR Group, which is headquartered in the United States." I also noted that NIU Invest intends to become an integrated mining operator with assets in North America, Latin America, Africa, and Europe, so doesn't appear to be going anywhere just building up. Its increased stake in CRTM appears to align with this wider expansion strategy. For that reason, I believe the recent share price uplift is more closely linked to NIU/GCR’s broader growth story rather than being solely tied to Molulu as such less likely susceptible to a share dump. GCR’s advisory board includes a former U.S. Army Brigadier General, which had me wondering about the Trump interest in growing the sector and seem to hvae the ability to buy some of the larger projects and meet senior politicians (“joining President Duma Boko (Botswana), who will officiate the opening of the mine, hosted by American firm GCR Group”). Developments like these are clearly influencing sentiment and, in turn, the share price. I can’t find any share listing for GCR’s Chilean or Botswana assets, but the trajectory indicates a much larger play than Molulu on its own. While pledges don’t always translate to execution, in this case capital has already been deployed with $200 million reportedly invested to revive and upgrade operations in Botswana, expected to generate more than 400 direct jobs and 3,000 indirect ones. Current job boards show over 40 vacancies posted, which reflects progress, though not yet the full scale announced. Even if Fryer decides to exit his position, it may not derail the bigger picture. At present, the momentum driving CRTM seems tied to its association with GCR/NIU’s moves rather than isolated project developments.  The big difference is Molulu isn't mining or holding reserves or Fryer could have pulled the wool over investor eyes again. Hopefully post rain season theres reporting of actually mining.

data.author: InvestPest
data.content: 1) There is copper is we believe Fryer initial reports (and cobalt) but the issue since the start is digging trenches isn't mining. Its a company built too soon on speculation without being able to come through after years of promises. 2) They built the school etc to give the locals something to stay for when not mining. The problem is by definition workers need work and move with it. The roads going to help them and the cab driving director move to the nearby mines for work and allow those mines a quicker and more efficient route to market. Molulu is now hemmed in by surrounding mines so expansions out the window but you tend to dig down and expand on finds so this shouldn't be a big problem. For shareholders though the elephants Fryers hold on shares, for whatever made up reason he has the profits will flow back to him unless the company delists and starts afresh but that has license implications. The problem won't be getting workers back to the site but actually realising Fryer left technically a dormant and inactive project which he can still impact by now buying and selling without disclosure (not that it stopped him before as we all know). I imagine his parting words as he left laughing in everyones faces was "when is a mine not a mine? When it’s a yours!

data.author: InvestPest
data.content: Why 20p? You need to prove production and thats the issue. A road was built that lends to the new miners in the area and the agreement with OM Metals fell apart as nothing mined to sell. What we need is the new CEO accountant to employ a miner and get the minerals out of the ground and sold. Thats 2 accountants and a cab driver now in charge of the company. A mine that mines is the aim and then we can consider 20p's and whatever else. Noted the Lebanese company who acquired their license until March 2030 taking the area of CRTM main cobalt vein. 4 months of rain now on the ground so not expecting the mining to be forthcoming until 2026 but at least no Fryer at the helm. I hold onto this as a beacon of hope.

data.author: bohercom
data.content: Ah yes, the $800k loan that CRTM ended up liable for.  What was the source of that $800k loan ?  How did CRTM end up liable for it ? Digging over old ground here, but whilst it was valid in the sense that it existed, I'm not sure it was valid in terms of it being a debt that CRTM incurred. CRTM, run by Fryer, bought a company owned by Fryer, paid Fryer a lot of money for that company, and as part of the transaction CRTM also took on the debt owed by that company to Fryer.  That company had no other way to pay Fryer back - but he created a situation whereby CRTM would pay it back. As I said - free shares.

data.author: bohercom
data.content: I'm assuming he's free to sell given that the recent prospectus detailed the agreements with him quite extensively, and they didn't mention any lock in period for his shares.  Given he's no longer a PDMR, why wouldn't he be free to sell ? "Almost free shares" - absolutely.  When you use someone else's money to buy a company you own for an inflated price, and when you grant yourself a bonus, also using someone else's money, when you've failed to achieve anything - and then you convert the payments for those things into shares - the shares are almost free.

I think with that appointment and him actively promoting Sino-Pak collaborations we can assume if China don't buy a mine in DRC they sure as hell will find a way to influence it:)

data.content: Selina Hayes: I’m pleased to share that I have joined the Board of Critical Metals PLC  as a Non-Executive Director. Looking at her other non-exec roles such as RareX Limited (ASX: REE) which went from $0.10 to $0.02 the last 9 months at least there's a similar trend. Primero Group (ASX: PGX) which was delisted pursuant to ASX Listing Rule 17.14 (NRW Holdings Limited buy out). Shareholders roughly 14% better off. The difference is that was a fully functioning minerals processing service and had revenue. CRTM is a scrapes in the ground and Russian affiliated new personnel. This looks more like a shell or a sale more than ever but to a network needing a shell it appears. Doesn't seem to matter how its wrapped up with board members.
